comments.text:
Pripyat is the name of the city next to the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant. 
It was evacuated after the disaster and is now a ghost town. You can go 
there on tours though. Chernobyl (the city) is around 15 km from the actual 
power plant. There are in fact people living in Chernobyl (only around 500 
according to Wikipedia). Mostly workers etc. living there temporarily, I 
would assume. Pripyat is an awesome city to explore though (very 
post-apocalyptic), and I would highly recommend visitting it (it isn't 
expensive). I was there in November 2011 with 15 other people (my current 
profile picture was taken in front of reactor 4).

conspiracy theories state that the gold is gone, but other priceless 
artifacts remain. Some speculate that dead alien bodies and UFOs sit inside 
the vault.  Speaking of UFOs, another Fort Knox conspiracy rests on the 
reputation of Lt. Col. Philip Corso.  He wrote a book about the Roswell 
incident being real.  Many believe the alien technology is being stored 
inside of Fort Knox.  Top secret shipments transferred from Area 51 to Fort 
Knox add fuel to the conspiracy. Another famous alien connection about Fort 
Knox is called the Mantell UFO Incident of 1948.  The Kentucky Air National 
Guard  sent out three pilots to check out a report of an unusual aerial 
object flying above Maysville, Kentucky.  One of the pilots, Thomas 
Mantell, found the object which was reported as being bright white and 
round with a red border at the bottom.  The object supposedly made its way 
over Fort Knox.  All this comes under the banner of *Conspiracy Theories* 
because *nobody, including yourself, actually knows!*

Please sit and listen to my cool experience. I actually can say I have been 
to Club 33 thanks to my ex gf and parents. I went there for her school 
prom(first prom they had there). Her parents paid (score!) for the both of 
us. $150 per person was the fee for us to go. Her private school had a hook 
up I guess. I had heard about Club 33 years before and when she asked me I 
was speechless and said YES of course! So when we went it was so awesome! 
All dressed up, we waited as a group in front of Disneyland till employees 
escorted us into the park. They walked us down main street as everyone 
stared at us wondering why we were all dressed up...(we felt like 
celebrities as guests were staring and taking photos as we walked by) We 
finally get to THE door and had to wait and take some photos then when went 
in and oh my was I shaking with happiness and excitement. It was 
awesome...We danced and had the night of our lives...oh and the gourmet 
buffet was so good! It was cool cause we were there after the park closed 
so we got to see the park at night basically empty as we were making out on 
the deck. Much fun. Never forget. Thanks for reading.﻿

I've been to Club 33 in Disneyland several times.  Members can allow guests 
to enter as well, and some memberships are corporate-owned, so not every 
visitor to Club 33 is a member.  The staff is exceptionally professional 
and the service is amazing.  There is also another exclusive club in 
Disneyland, located in the California Adventure Park, known as 1901 Lounge, 
which, unlike Club 33, requires the member to be in attendance with any 
guests.﻿

credible proponent...a simple example being that if Lucy were to have 
evolved into the current version of human anatomy she would need to have 
dozens of bridge anatomical structure humans in the evolutionary process 
 to convert her structure to the current human frame and anatomy...and to 
date they have never found 1 bridge structure of any kind to bridge these 
massive inconsistencies...there is not 1 missing link needed for this 
theory to hold any water, there are at the least dozens...evolution is a 
process, not a redesign from scratch based on 
similarities...the assumptions simply do not hold up under scrutiny or 
evidence to the contrary...another being that if this gradual evolutionary 
process from apes to humans were valid, and there are currently apes and 
humans on the planet- where are the half ape-half human creatures that are 
undergoing this evolutionary process...and where are the predecessors to 
the apes at...and the half-predecessor-half apes at...and so on right down 
the line...there are apes, there are humans, there are predecessors...but 
where is even a single creature that is in this evolutionary process 
today...certainly evolution has not stopped...it is ongoing...or have the 
apes stopped turning into pre-humans...the simple fact is that not 1 single 
piece of the dozens of missing link bridge creatures necessary for that 
model of evolution has ever been found, ever...via archaeologists or via 
anatomists...at some point egos within the evolutionary society must give 
in to the massive amounts of scrutiny backed by solid science and either 
scrap that theory or model a new one...but that will be like turning around 
the titanic on a dime...until then have fun betting against that crowd 
on them ever finding the magical missing link(s)...take care

comments.text:
+E ante         I'm reluctant to tell you all that happened because it 
wouldn't do any good; you still wouldn't believe me. But until you've lived 
my life, it is unfair for you to assume that there's an easy explanation 
for it. You haven't seen what I've seen, and you haven't experienced what I 
have. Maybe if you did, you would think otherwise. But anyway, they *can* 
be explained, but not with something stupid like "aliens". Considering the 
incidents I'm talking about, the belief that God is behind them makes 
perfect sense. But until you've experienced my life (Which, unfortunately, 
you never will be able to) you'll never be able to see that it makes sense. 
There's no way I can prove it to you, and I regret that. But I'm not going 
to stop believing because I know what I've seen. 
 
       And why do you say that believing God did it is a lazy answer? If 
it’s the only thing that makes sense, then how is that just being “lazy”? 
I’m not talking about looking at some random thing I don’t understand and 
just shrugging and declaring God magically makes it work. No. I have looked 
at all the possibilities, and I would be a fool to believe it was caused by 
something else. Saying God is behind it is the only thing that makes sense. 
I’m not talking about a simple hoax from a parent or pastor, I’m not 
talking about something stupid like saying a random dream is proof of God 
or something, and I’m not talking about something that has plenty of better 
answers. You believe what you want to, but I *know* what I’ve seen, and I 
know I’m not crazy or lying. Like I keep saying, unfortunately, there’s no 
way to prove this to anyone else, so this discussion is probably pointless, 
but if you could have seen what I’m talking about, if you had been me, then 
I’m sure you would have a different attitude about it….
 
       Anyway, at the end, you said *”if we can explain anything we know 
today it is thanks to scientists not God. “* Now you’re committing a 
fallacy. You’re assuming God doesn’t exist, and offering that as valid 
proof that everything scientists have found has nothing to do with Him. If 
God exists, then of course He would have helped them or at least allowed 
them to find what they’ve found. Besides, even if God just left them alone 
and let them discover what they could, how does that invalidate His 
existence? If He just created the world around them and let them loose like 
a parent lets a little kid loose in a scavenger hunt to find what they 
could find, that wouldn’t be “proof’ for Him not existing… Now, let me ask 
you something else. Have you been able to look at all the facts for every 
discovery? Have you been able to prove without a shadow of a doubt, and 
with actual proof, not just personal assumptions, that God didn’t 
intervene? I guess these are the main things I’m trying to say here: That 
the fact that you don’t think God exists is not actual proof that He hasn’t 
intervened in scientific discoveries. First you’d have to be able to 
completely disprove Him and any other concept of a god, which is pretty 
much impossible. Then, even if He didn’t intervene, it still doesn’t mean 
He doesn’t exist. He could have just wanted people to find out what they 
could on their own, kind of like with the analogy I gave about the little 
kid in the scavenger hunt.
 
       Alright, sorry for rambling, but one last thing. At the beginning 
you said *”We don't have prove that he exists, so he probably doesn't.”* 
I’m guessing that you made a typo here and meant to say “We don’t have 
proof”; instead of “We don’t have prove”. Anyway, I’m just going to assume 
you were trying to say proof, and make my points based off of that. If I 
misunderstood, please correct me. Anyway, there is proof that God exists. 
All you have to do is some research, and you’ll find many things about the 
Bible that really point to God. Case in point:

http://www.alphanewsdaily.com/mathprophecy1.html

       Another thing. Jesus Himself definitely existed, we have proof for 
that. The question is, was He God or just a normal person? If you do more 
research on the matter, you’ll see many more things in support that He was 
God. If you look at the highly complex things around us in our world and 
Universe, you’ll see it’s more likely for God to have created everything 
then for it to have all come about by chance.

       Yes, but what I mean is, these "miracles" if you want to call them, 
have only one valid explanation. Anything else would be grasping for 
straws. For instance, someone could say it was "government technology" or 
"aliens" but that sounds a whole lot crazier (And is so unlikely it 
shouldn't even be considered a real possibility.) than the notion that God 
is behind them. It's virtually impossible for anyone to have faked the 
things I'm talking about, and to make it even more unrealistic, they would 
have had no reason to. I wish I could prove I'm not lying, but 
unfortunately, I can't. But since I, personally, know that I'm telling the 
truth, and I know what I've seen, it gives me extra basis to believe in God.
 
       EDIT: I just realized something else. The original point Drei was 
talking about in explaining things was *about how everything must be 
explainable to be considered science.* To which I replied by talking about 
different things in science that couldn't be explained, to which you 
replied by saying that everything could be explained eventually. Basically, 
it went like this. *Drei*) God isn't explainable, therefore does not = 
science. *Me*) Some things in science aren't explainable but are still 
considered science. *You*) Everything can be explained eventually.

       Okay, if everything can be explained eventually, who's to say God 
can't be explained eventually? Therefore, you can't really say God isn't 
"science" because He's unexplainable, because you still consider those 
other things I mentioned science even though they can't be explained 
either. Therefore, that point is invalid. Just because we can't explain 
something yet or don't know how it works doesn't mean it doesn't exist. And 
besides, if God exists, why is it so hard for you to believe He could break *His 
own laws?*
       Therefore, it seems the debate shouldn't whether God can break His 
own laws, but does He exist or not?

comments.text:
+Drei88
       Think about it this way. We're discussing the idea of an 
all-powerful being. If said being existed, it would have created the laws, 
and be able to bend them at any time, hence the term "all-powerful". Of 
course, if you aren't acknowledging its existence at all, you wouldn't 
expect it to be able to do anything, much less break any universal laws.

       As for the thing about the miracles, I *have* tried to comprehend 
them and see if there were any other explanations. I'm not talking about 
some kind of "simple hoax". You said yourself I seemed intelligent. Don't 
you think if some person tried to "fake a miracle" or something to keep me 
believing, I would have figured it out? The things I've seen can't have 
been done by anybody else, and don't have any other reasonable 
explanations. I don't expect you to just believe me or automatically become 
a Christian because of what I'm saying. I understand that unfortunately, I 
have no way to prove it to you, and I never will. But I know what I've 
seen, and I know there's no way someone else faked it...  Besides, I'm not 
talking about telepathy, levitation, or the thing about only 10% of the 
mind being used. Those things have nothing to do with my beliefs. What's 
funny, though, is that you mentioned Star Trek TNG. I'm actually a huge fan 
of that show. XD

       But anyway, there's one more thing I'd like to point out. You said *"The 
thing with science is that it is required by definition to be explainable."* 
There are many things in science (That Atheists and Christians alike hold 
as fact) that cannot be explained, or have yet to be explained. Like what 
happens beyond a black hole's horizon. Sure, you can hypothesize, but you 
can't give a definite explanation. Or why light travels so fast. Or why (or 
how) gravity pullls things in. Maybe some of the things I listed can be 
explained, but even so, there are many things that aren't explainable, yet 
still considered science. All you have to do is Google "things that science 
can't explain" and a ton of articles will come up listing all of the things 
that aren't explainable. Besides, most Atheists (The ones that don't even 
consider the possibility of a god or God existing) consider the Big Bang's 
start science, yet no one can explain what started it or how the "point of 
singularity" got there in the first place. Now, please don't hear what I'm 
not saying. I'm not trying to debate the validity of the Big Bang, I 
already stated that I believe it. I'm just trying to point out that all 
it's aspects are not explainable, yet are still considered science.

comments.text:
+Drei88
        Well, to be honest, I have researched the story of Noah in detail, 
and I will admit it seems pretty impossible- at first. Earlier I was in a 
debate about it, and the fellow I was debating with brought up 10 very 
interesting, seemingly fool-proof points. After extensive research, I found 
answers for pretty much all of them. If you'd like, maybe I could 
copy/paste the discussion here or something.

       Anyway, about the infinite mass thing, well, that's a bit harder to 
explain. If it was really all powerful, it could bend the known laws of 
science and the Universe and make itself not have infinite mass. Or, 
perhaps, since it would have created the entire Universe, perhaps it could 
exist outside of it, and use it's power to interact with the Universe's 
inhabitants. There are different possible explanations, but if a being was 
all powerful, surely there would be things we couldn't hope to understand 
about it yet. Now, I will be honest about something. I have yet to 
thoroughly research evolution, but I plan on doing it soon.

       However, I have a few reasons why I believe in God, even if the 
proof was in evolution's favor. For one, I have seen Him do supernatural 
works in my life, that can't be explained any other way, psychologically, 
or physically. Unfortunately, there's no way I can prove this to you or 
anyone else, and I'm sure you'll think I'm nuts or lying, so it's not 
really a good "point" for debating. I might as well be saying I traveled 
back in time and had tea with a ghost. But I know what I've seen, and it's 
kept me believing in God. Another thing that keeps me reluctant about 
evolution, even if I didn't believe in God, is all the chance involved.

       Sure, +E ante, you seem to have a good explanation about the 
mutations, but it still amazes me that even simple cells (which are still 
incredibly complex) could have "learned" how to repair mutations in the 
first place. I put the quotation marks because cells aren't really 
sentient. But speaking of being sentient, how did mindless simple life 
forms eventually cross the "bridge", if you want to call it that, to 
actually being sentient? And all by random mutations and adaptations? There 
are many things that I don't know how they came to be on their own, like 
memories, being able to visualize images in our heads, personalities and 
will, etc... Sure, some of those things might have logical explanation that 
I just haven't heard yet, but surely all of it couldn't have come about by 
chance, right? I just don't have enough faith to believe in those kinds of 
odds... And even if all the current evidence points towards evolution, 
who's to say we just haven't found the evidence that disproves it yet? 
Besides, there are still some flaws in the theory, as I said in an earlier 
post.

        Anyway, I'll try to do more research in the future, so I can make 
more detailed and intelligent points in discussions like these....
comments.author: Seth Wallace

comments.author: Drei88

comments.text:
+Seth Wallace Firstly, yes, evolution in all terms (macro or micro) is 
fundamental to biology. At least at the moment until someone comes with 
scientific proof which can be PEER REVIEWED and proves it is wrong and that 
some other hypothesis is correct.

And coming to your point about mutations "Aren't mutations supposed to be 
harmful It's really hard to believe that a series of random mutations (That 
would be harmful, at the least, 95% of the time) could form more and more 
complicated creatures, until it got to us."

There are many kinds of mutations, some of them don't cause harm, since 
they can happen in what is thought of as non-coding parts (or parts not 
being used in that particular cell) of the DNA (and I would like to make it 
clear, it is thought of, or it was thought of recently, it's a 
hypotheses).And if they occur in the coding parts, some don't matter 
towards the final outcome (the protein), although this is rare, also there 
are many ways by which the cell can repair mutations, one of them is the 
SOS method, but there are more.

If a mutation occurs the fact that there are millions of cells and 
thousands or millions of members in a species makes its effect lower. On 
the other hand, some mutations can benefit the cell or organism by creating 
new proteins which can have different functions to the original one, 
although this can be rare. One of the cases in which it happens and by 
which it can help our body is in the secondary immunity, if mutations occur 
in the section of DNA which codes for the variable region of our antibodies 
or antigen receptors this can give us an advantage, since maybe that 
receptor or antibody can attach to a different epitope (the part of an 
antigen to which the antibody binds to) leading to immunity against a new 
pathogen or a mutated pathogen.﻿

In the case of individual cells, the mutations can be helpfull since in 
some cases it leads to variations which are favourable under certain 
conditions, such as a bacteria which tolerates better heat since its 
proteins won't denature at higher temperatures.
comments.author: E ante

comments.text:
+Drei88
         Well, it seems most of your points have been riddled with insults 
targeted at my beliefs. They haven't really offended me, but I was a little 
annoyed that it seemed your last post mainly consisted of mocking 
Christianity and other random things like that instead of valid points. 
Anyway, E ante already complained about my last article, so I admitted that 
it had less to do with evolution, that I had thrown it in there for good 
measure, and that I had kind of skimmed it over. No one ever said anything 
about the other ones, though, and they had less to do with Christianity and 
more to do with pointing out flaws in evolution. Like I've said before, I'm 
really busy, and it's a miracle I've been able to respond to you so fast 
lately. We both know it can take me weeks to reply. Why? Because I'm really 
busy, (I'm only about 17 and still in school as well) and in over my head 
in other discussions that take up time.

       Anyway, as to your question at the end. You said *"how many atheists 
deny the fundamentals of biology, archaeological findings, history, and the 
laws of thermodynamics governing the conservation of mass and energy?"*. It 
seems you're trying to point out that Christians often deny the 
fundamentals of biology, archeology, etc... Usually, the Christians who 
"deny" the fundamentals of those things simply haven't done thorough 
research yet, or really misrepresent the Bible, thus making it look worse 
than it really is.

       The Christians *who have done their research* usually don't deny 
those things, just stuff like macroevolution. I don't know if you consider 
that fundamental to biology or whatever, but other than that, they don't 
really deny much else you would consider fact. It seems to me there are 
three groups of people when it comes to Christianity VS Atheism. The first 
group would consist of the people who never really took the time to 
research the "scientific" matters about the Bible, but believe it based off 
of other things. The second one would consist of people who did some 
research, and based off of that, think that the first group consists of 
"ignorant" or uneducated people. For instance, when I say "some" research, 
I mean this. Surely you've heard of the seeming "contradictions" in the 
Bible, right? If an Atheist did a little bit of research on the Bible, and 
came up with these "contradictions", they might be content to say they had 
disproved the Bible and refuse to believe in it. Likewise, they might do a 
little bit of research on evolution, and not find any of it's problems or 
flaws, and easily deduce it was correct and the Bible was wrong, thus 
prompting them to look down on the people in the first group.

       Then, what I'd consider the third group to be, is the people who 
have done in depth research on both matters. If you dig deeper into the 
Bible, you'll see that there are very reasonable answers for all of the 
"contradictions". And, likewise, if you do some heavy research on 
evolution, you'll find its flaws as well. You'll also find that the Bible 
isn't exactly specific on how long it took for the Earth to form.
       However, you'll even find evidence for the young-Earth theory. Sound 
absurd? Allow me to explain. (Please note, I still don’t exactly believe in 
the Young-Earth theory, but I thought these points sounded interesting and 
made it sound a bit more credible.) For one, there’s something called the 
“Genesis Code” or something… I’m a little bit fuzzy on the details, but it 
goes something like this: That at the start of the Big Bang, everything was 
moving a lot faster because of the explosion from the point of singularity. 
Therefore, when the Earth was formed, billions of years worth of time 
passed in 6 24-hour periods, or days. According to the theory, “time” (How 
fast everything in the Universe was moving) eventually slowed down to what 
it is today. Again, I’m a bit fuzzy on it, so I probably misrepresented it 
some. Anyway, sounded interesting in my opinion. Another theory (that some 
non-Christians have adopted) is that light used to move faster.   

http://www.dailygalaxy.com/my_weblog/2012/08/light-traveled-faster-in-the-early-universe-todays-most-popular.html
    That would invalidate the proof of a billions of years old Universe 
that’s based off of how far away stars are, if it's true. What I mean is 
this. Some people say that the fact that some stars are billions of light 
years away prove that the Universe is billions of years old. And at first 
glance they’d be right. But if light used to be faster, that particular 
argument would be invalidated. These and a few other theories seem pretty 
interesting, but again, I’m not out to prove the Earth is 6000 years old. 
The Bible isn’t specific on the matter.

comments.text:
+motownflame In an earlier post (not sure if it was a reply to mine or not) 
you said evolution was the process whereby all life was created. This is 
incorrect. Evolution describes a process whereby life, that already exists, 
develops. The beginning of life is not a part of the theory. Until you have 
something that is capable of reproducing, evolution makes little sense. 
Naturalists believe some form of abiogenesis first occurred. Whereas 
evolution involves time spans well beyond that of a human life; there is no 
reason to think a process of abiogenesis would and; therefore, any theory 
about such a process would have to be confirmed in a laboratory. To date, 
no experiment has produced abiogenesis.

+motownflame Devolving and evolving in a sense already exists for Humans 
due to our advances in technology. Better medicine and health care and 
easier access to food due to transportation and farming means many of us 
live much longer lives than those even only about 100 years ago. People 
born with disabilities or health conditions also survive a lot longer now 
due to medicine, as a Type 1 diabetic myself a few hundred years ago I 
would have died within a very short time in my life but nowadays with 
access to insulin and means to check my sugar levels I can live a long 
normal life.

Also with us having ease of transport and removal of predators we live in 
an environment where many of us can still live long lives while not being 
particularly physically active or over eating, in the wild an unfit animal 
would not survive but for us we can survive just sitting on our butts all 
day at a computer or driving everywhere and pass on our genes. That and 
unlike other animals which mate for survival and look for a suitable mate 
who could produce fit offspring, humans tend to find partners for 
companionship and so more intellectual things like personalty are what 
attract us to one another even if our partner isn't some olympic athlete of 
peak human fitness.

captions.text:
• From clubs exclusive to rich tycoons and
the social elite to interesting islands off-limits

from tourists to prevent contamination, we
count 15 places you'd really like to visit

once, but you have almost no chance to do
so

15 - Svalbard Global Seed Vault,
• This one was built out of fear that all

those sci-fi scenarios about the end of the
world might actually come true

• This vault, build on a secluded island
in the North Sea, is home to over 250 million

crop seeds shipped from gene banks worldwide
with an estimated cost exceeding $9 million

dollars
• You can't enter the vault - nobody can,

but researchers, plant breeders and other
groups can request seeds from the depositing

genebanks
• If you WERE to enter it, you'd see the

biggest hope for agriculture in the event
of a polar ice cap melt or similar Earthly

disaster
14 - Mezhgorye,

• A closed military town at the foot of
Mount Yamantau, believed by the United States

to be a large secret nuclear facility owned
by the Russians

• When questioned, the Russians give inconsistent
answers like, it's a mining site, no, it's

a treasury, no, a food storage area - and
then finally they said, yep, nuclear bunker

in the event of apocalyptic war
• It's believed to house nuclear weapons,

and as much as we want to visit it to inspect,
we aren't allowed - Russian newspapers claim

it to be part of the Dead Hand initiative
- to automatically launch nukes if a bunch

are about to strike THEM
13 - Woomera Prohibited Area,

• An Australian military testing range covering
nearly 124,000 square kilometres - and although

that area is restricted, the nearby town of
Woomera is open to the public

• You'll want to go there for one reason,
but also want to stay away for another - it's

highly prospective, significant quantities
of minable gold, iron ore, opals and uranium

that the general populace can't reach
• Due to the amount of unlaunched war material

lying around though, it's basically a minefield,
so even if you could get around the military

presence to mine, chances are you'll get your
face blown off - not a great way to spend

your weekend
12 - Jiangsu National Security Education Museum,

• This is basically the real-life James
Bond exhibit - top secret documents and gadgets

from the history of Chinese espionage
• It includes things like, guns disguised

as lipstick, hollowed-out coins to conceal
documents and maps hidden in a deck of cards

• The only people allowed to enter this
museum are Chinese nationals, entirely because

they don't trust foreigners with their sensitive
spy information - which is fair enough

11 - Club 33,
• A private club located in Disneyland that

costs 40 thousand dollars for membership and
$10,000 in yearly costs

• The reason it costs so much? It's like
a secret backdoor disneyland but with a liquor

license and 14-year waiting list, props from
disney films everywhere, animatronics and

complimentary valet parking
• You enter the club by buzzing an intercom

concealed in a hidden panel in the doorway,
then you take the antique-style glass lift

to any of two giant dining rooms
• This is a great place if you're an ultra-rich

tycoon
10 - Aldwych Tube Station,

• A subway station active during World War
II, also used as an air raid shelter and hiding

place for National Gallery artworks
• In 1994 the trains stopped running and

now the entire station is unused, a monument
to early 1900s society with vintage tracks,

an old lobby and ancient elevators
• On occasion it's open for tours, but for

99% of the time people just break in to take
photos

9 - Fort Knox,
• The location of a fortified vault building,

the United States Bullion Depository located
in Kentucky, used to store large portions

of gold and precious items
• Today it holds 4,500 metric tons of pure

gold, built inside granite walls, protected
by a blast-proof door, weighing 22 tons and

21-inches tick, 30,000 soldiers patrolling
with tanks, personal carriers, attack helicopters

and artillery
• In order to enter you need a 10 part secret

code held by 10 different people all in different
locations - there's a reason we have the saying

"as impenetrable as Fort Knox"
8 - White's Gentleman's Club,

• Established in 1693, this is a club exclusive
for British men with notable members Prince

Charles, Prince William, the Duke of Cambridge
and the British Prime Minister

• For hundreds of years, a famous betting
book has seen notable figures gambling on

not just sport, but political developments
even during the French Revolution and Napoleonic

Wars
• Women who approach the club are always

denied membership, including the model for
the central character in the BBC television

series and one of the best chefs during the
early 1900s: Rosa Lewis

7 - Queen's Bedroom,
• You'll find this in Buckingham Palace,

the British Queen's official London residence
first established in 1705

• Even though the place is heavily guarded,
one man managed to break in and hide in the

Queen's bedroom in 1982
• To date, he's one of the only men to see

the interior without an official Royal Family
invitation or building permit - and if you're

just some random shmo like me, then there's
little chance we'll see it this lifetime

6 - Lascaux Caves (las-co),
• Located in France, one of the most important

archaological finds - that of cave paintings
and perfectly preserved footprints from human

beings that lived tens of thousands of years
ago

• Due to the fear of fungal infection from
human presence, these caves have been closed

to the public for some time and on rare occasions
only a small group of people escorted over

elevated ramps can visit for minutes at any
given time

• You can learn more about it in the documentary
"Cave of Forgotten Dreams" one of the few

pieces of photography allowed in the cave
network

5 - Area 51,
• And yes, I'm sure a lot of you are relatively

close by to this Nevada military site 83 miles
north of Las Vegas

• Officially, it's a U.S owned military
airfield whose primary purpose is to test

experimental aircraft and weapon systems
• Unofficially, we know it as a super secret

Alien landing strip filled with the dead corpses
of a 100,000 deceased martians that all landed

on a certain day in 1947
4 - Surtsey,

• An Icelandic island that only came into
existence about 50 years ago following volcanic

eruptions in the area
• Despite its young age, the island already

plays host to over 90 species of bird with
new plant species evolving at a rate of 2-5

per year
• Humans carefully monitor the islands progress

from a small hut, ensuring no outside seeds
or unwanted visitors turn up to hurt the naturally

evolving ecosystem - they even had to dig
up some potatoes a bunch of kids planted for

a laugh
3 - Air Force One,

• The official plane of the President of
the United States, first designed during 1953

with many replacements ever since
• It comes with an electromagnetic pulse

shield that can fly through highly irradiated
zones from nuclear fallout, deploy missiles,

jam radars, and it doesn't need to land to
refuel

• During the events of 9/11, then-president
George Bush was flown around in Air Force

One and even detected threats from other passing
airliners which later turned out to be miscommunication

2 - Poveglia,
• A small island near Venice that many claim

to have had such an intense, violent history
that it's now haunted

• It was once a dumping ground for the sick,
dying and deceased, and when the Bubonic Plague

arrived in 1348, it became a quarantine zone
with Venice exiling many ill people there

• It was immolated when the Black Death
swept through, a hospital for the mentally

ill was established and shut down and currently
it's now closed to both locals and tourists

1 - Room 39
• A rumoured secret government organisation

in North Korea dedicated to maintaining the
foreign currency slush funds of Kim Jong - fancy

talk for money laundering
• Though its activities are seen as illegal,

it holds as much as $5 billion in funds and
not TECHNICALLY supported on an official level

even though it's critical to Kim Jong's seat
of power

• Today, it fetches over a billion dollars
each year through criminal activity and no,

they won't let you inspect their papers or
affiliated locations - so don't plan a vacation
there

title: 15 Magical Places You're Not Allowed To Visit
